title: Modified Early Warning Score (MEWS) for Clinical Deterioration
description: Determines the degree of illness of a patient and identifies patients at risk of clinical deterioration using physiological parameters

parameters.name: heart_rate
parameters.description: Heart rate in beats per minute

parameters.name: respiratory_rate
parameters.description: Respiratory rate in breaths per minute

parameters.name: consciousness_level
parameters.description: Level of consciousness using AVPU scale

result.name: mews_score
result.description: Modified Early Warning Score indicating degree of illness

ranges.interpretation: Continue routine monitoring. Standard nursing observations as per protocol.
Increase monitoring frequency. Consider medical review within 1-2 hours. Alert healthcare team.
Immediate medical review required. Consider ICU consultation. Significantly increased risk of death or ICU admission.

references: Subbe CP, Kruger M, Rutherford P, Gemmel L. Validation of a modified Early Warning Score in medical admissions. QJM. 2001 Oct;94(10):521-6. doi: 10.1093/qjmed/94.10.521.
Morgan RJM, Williams F, Wright MM. An early warning scoring system for detecting developing critical illness. Clinical Intensive Care. 1997;8:100.

Goldhill DR, McNarry AF, Mandersloot G, McGinley A. A physiologically-based early warning score for ward patients: the association between score and outcome. Anaesthesia. 2005 Jun;60(6):547-53. doi: 10.1111/j.1365-2044.2005.04186.x.
formula: Sum of points from systolic BP (0-3), heart rate (0-3), respiratory rate (0-3), temperature (0-2), and consciousness level (0-3). Total range: 0-14 points.
notes: Score ≥5 associated with increased likelihood of death or ICU admission
Any single parameter scoring 3 points suggests need for higher level of care
Originally developed for medical patients, validated in surgical populations
Some institutions may modify parameters or thresholds
Should be used as part of comprehensive clinical assessment
Designed for use by trained healthcare providers in hospital settings
